results.title: A Demonstration of basic film techniques
results.brief_description: Designed to serve as a practical aid for teachers presenting a course in film appreciation. Experience has shown that one of the first barriers to be broken down in such a course is the students’ ignorance of the fact that a film is MADE, that it is the result of conscious decision by the film maker. Teachers may use it to demonstrate the more common shots in film making. They may use it to establish the idea of film editing - the joining together of separate shots into a meaningful unit. The film’s deficiencies and faults should serve as valuable teaching points during discussion after the film.

results.title: The Davis Cup, 1951
results.brief_description: The story of Australia’s fight to retain the world tennis premiership. The film covers the Interzone Final in Melbourne between Sweden and the USA and the Challenge Round in Sydney between the USA and Australia. Narrated by Michael Charlton and Peter Whitchurch.

results.title: David and Jennifer Learn Their Kerb Drill
results.creator_credit: Rhonda Small, John Martin-Jones, Australian Road Safety Council and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: David and Jennifer are sent on messages to a shop across a busy street. Their mother carefully explains the meaning of the traffic lights. They sing a safety song to remember the newly learnt rules.

results.title: The Dandenong Story
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Thompson and Cine Service Productions
results.brief_description: Dandenong, Victoria, named after an Aboriginal tribe, is a fast growing town. As the gateway to Gippsland and the Latrobe Valley, it is important for agriculture. But even more significant is the development of big industrial plants manufacturing goods such as carpets, trucks, cars and fruit cans. Such decentralization of industry is bringing prosperity and a high standard of living to Dandenong and Australia as a whole.

results.title: The Cow and the sprite
results.brief_description: One of a series of films which puppets are used to interpret folk legends. The film is an adaptation of an old Scotch-Irish folk story that tells of the happiness of man and of what it is composed.

results.title: The Country Roads Board gazette No. 10
results.brief_description: Progress report on work of the Country Roads Board; rebuilding the Warrigal Road and the Nepean Highway intersection; new road bridge across the Maribyrnong River at Footscray; construction of a new Air Force air strip; digging storm water drains in the metropolitan areas; maintenance and building of country roads and bridges.

results.title: The Challenge
results.creator_credit: Jack Rogers, Frank Killian and Ampol Petroleum Ltd
results.brief_description: This is a tribute to the Australians who sailed Gretel” in the America’s Cup…” Traces the construction of the Australian challenger, “Gretel”, its trials in America, and finally its efforts in the America’s Cup yacht races.

results.title: Cave temples of India
results.creator_credit: Jagat Murari, M. Bhavnani and Documentary Films of India
results.brief_description: A vivid reminder of a great past when people created miracles in stone to express devotion to their gods. Shows some of the famous rock-cut shrines, including the caves at Badami, Elephanta and Ellora, dating from the 17th century. Explains the statues depicting the various incarnations of the Hindu deity. Commentary by Berkeley Hill.

results.title: Special Project no. 14: Marlo-Mallacoota-Cape Conran
results.brief_description: The Country Roads Board’s Project no. 14 involves the building of a road from Orbost to Marlo. Shows the first section to Cape Conran and difficulties encountered in clearing and leveling the sandy loam. The area opened by the road has great development potential in its attractive surf beaches, bushland and off-shore oil drilling. Photography by Jim Stirling.

results.title: The Burnie story
results.creator_credit: Associated Pulp and Paper Manufacturers and Cine Service
results.brief_description: The township of Burnie on the north-west coast of Tasmania with a population of 14,000 is the centre of the thriving pulp and paper manufacturing industry. This industry started in 1936 and produces from the forests in the surrounding country, not only timber for the building industry but from the timber waste all types of cardboard, and wrapping paper and even high-grade printing paper. The film shows the up-to-date and powerful machinery which is used from the time a tree is felled until the final paper product is shipped from the Burnie wharves. Afforestation is maintained to ensure the raw material will not be exhausted. Photography: Geoffrey Thompson. Narrated by Ray Chapman.
